channel.title: People News@Emory
channel.description: All the latest news from Emory University.

item.title: Emory Community Mourns Rudolph Byrd
item.description: Read a letter from Provost Earl Lewis about the loss of Rudolph Byrd, Goodrich C. White Professor of American Studies, remembered as 'a consummate teacher' and 'institution-builder.'

item.title: Emory Professor Honored for Work With Incarcerated Women
item.description: When Elizabeth M. Bounds of Emory University's Candler School of Theology followed her call, it landed her in jail - voluntarily.

item.title: Emory Ethicist Nominated for World Technology Award
item.description: Paul Root Wolpe, director of Emory University's Center for Ethics, has been named a finalist for a prestigious World Technology Award in Ethics, to be presented by the World Technology Network at the United Nations next week.

item.title: 'Accidental Slaveowner' Author to Give Reading at Emory Oct. 24
item.description: Author Mark Auslander will hold a public reading and book signing next week at Emory University to discuss his new release, "The Accidental Slaveowner: Revisiting a Myth of Race and Finding an American Family."

item.title: CNN Dialogues Forum on Social Media to Feature Top Trendmakers Oct. 12
item.description: CNN Dialogues will host its second event, "Living in the Age of Social Media - the Good, the Bad and the Surprising," on Wednesday, Oct. 12 at 7 p.m. Panelists include musician Pete Wentz, innovator Baratunde Thurston, author Maggie Jackson and pastor Shaun King.

item.title: A Geologist Paints Darwin
item.description: Emory geologist Woody Hickcox paints a mural of Charles Darwin during a night at the Fernbank Museum of Natural History. The mural is part of an exhibit of art inspired by evolution, in celebration of the museum's special Darwin exhibit.

item.title: 2011 Emory Medalists Honored for Dedication to the Greater Good
item.description: Two of Emory University's most distinguished and dedicated graduates will receive one of the university's highest honors, the Emory Medal, Thursday, Oct. 6 in a special ceremony on campus.

item.title: Fossil Hunter Mary Anning Inspires Art
item.description: Fiber artist Robey Tapp, who also serves as a docent at the Carlos Museum, created a piece inspired by Mary Anning, a self-taught paleontologist and fossil hunter who made important discoveries along England's Jurassic Coast. The art is part of the special Darwin exhibit at the Fernbank Museum.

item.title: Emory Alumnus Wins MacArthur Fellowship
item.description: Tiya Miles, who received her master's degree in Women's Studies from Emory University in 1995, has been named one of 22 new MacArthur Fellows for 2011.

item.title: Emory Biologist Among Popular Science's 'Brilliant 10'
item.description: Emory University biologist Jaap de Roode is among this year's "Brilliant 10," top scientists under 40 recognized by the editors of Popular Science magazine.

item.title: Emory Sociologist to Study Racial Apathy
item.description: Tyrone Forman, an Emory University sociologist and co-director of the university's Race and Difference Initiative, has won a prestigious fellowship from Stanford University, serving as a visiting fellow at the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences in Palo Alto, Calif., for the 2011-2012 academic year.

item.title: At the Decatur Book Festival: Images From Haitian Life After Disaster
item.description: Emory staff photographer and documentarian Bryan Meltz's images capture the country as life continued in the year after the earthquake. Her book will be featured at the AJC Decatur Book Festival, where she will be signing books in the Emory tent on Sunday, Sept. 4 at 1:30 p.m.

item.title: Falcons Name Karas New Team Doctor
item.description: Spero Karas, MD, orthopedic surgeon at the Emory Sports Medicine Center, has been named Head Team Physician for the NFL's Atlanta Falcons.

item.title: Rushdie Named to New Position at Emory
item.description: Acclaimed author Salman Rushdie will continue his affiliation with Emory University with a new title, as University Distinguished Professor, reflecting more expansive activities, according to an announcement by University Provost Earl Lewis.
